thread.title: Airlines canceling flights due to California storms
thread.title_full: Airlines canceling flights due to California storms

author: Dawn Gilbertson , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: Airlines canceling flights due to California storms
text:
A Southwest Airlines plane is parked on the side of a runway at Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport. (Photo: Michael Chow/The Republic)
21 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Travelers headed to California for the long Presidents Day weekend face flight delays and cancellations due to a monster storm expected to last through Saturday. Forecasts call for the most rain in six years in southern California.
American Airlines says it canceled eight departures to California from Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport on Friday: four to Orange County, two each to Long Beach and Burbank and one each to Los Angeles and San Diego. Overall, American has canceled 40 flights out of California on Friday.
Southwest Airlines said it canceled 250 California flights in total but did not break down Phoenix cancellations. FlightAware.com shows that Southwest has canceled 21 flights to California from Phoenix so far today.
RELATED: Sky Harbor Airport had fewer passengers in 2016 | American Airlines is shrinking in Phoenix | Southwest: No plans for basic economy fare
Altogether, airlines have canceled 66 flights between Phoenix and California so far, Sky Harbor spokesman Greg Roybal said.
Travelers whose flights are canceled can get a refund or rebook.
If your flight is not canceled but you want to avoid the storm, airlines are allowing travelers to change their tickets without the usual hefty fees. On most carriers, though, you can only move your flight into next week. At American and United, for example, the rebooked trip must start by Feb. 21. Southwest gives travelers a two-week rebooking window.
Southwest doesn't charge a change fee, so travelers who don't want to get caught in the mess have the option of canceling their flight and receiving a credit for the ticket price The credit must be used by the ticket holder within a year.
Here are major airlines' travel advisories and policies relating to the California storms:
American
Southwest
United
Delta
